nodes.prefixed:
<tei-TEI data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" data-origname="TEI" data-origatts="xmlns:xi xmlns">
 <tei-teiHeader data-origname="teiHeader">
      <tei-fileDesc data-origname="fileDesc">
        <tei-titleStmt data-origname="titleStmt">
           <tei-title data-origname="title">Monsieur Acarete du Biscay's Journey from Buenos Ayres to Peru</tei-title>
           <tei-author data-origname="author">Acarete du Biscay</tei-author>
        </tei-titleStmt>
        <tei-publicationStmt data-origname="publicationStmt">
           <tei-p data-origname="p">An Account of a voyage up the river de la Plata, and thence over land to Peru. With observations on the inhabitants, as well Indians and Spaniards; the cities, commerce, fertility, and riches of that part of America</tei-p>
        </tei-publicationStmt>
        <tei-sourceDesc data-origname="sourceDesc">
           <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">
  <tei-title data-origname="title">Monsieur Acarete Du Biscay’s journey from Buenos Aires to Perú</tei-title>. In
 <tei-author data-origname="author">Du Biscay, Acarete</tei-author>. <tei-publisher data-origname="publisher">Voyages and Discoveries in South America, vol. II</tei-publisher>. <tei-editor data-origname="editor">S. Buckley. World Digital Library</tei-editor><tei-date data-origname="date">1698</tei-date>. </tei-bibl>
        </tei-sourceDesc>
      </tei-fileDesc>
      <tei-profileDesc data-origname="profileDesc">
         <tei-langUsage data-origname="langUsage">
            <tei-language ident="eng" data-origname="language" data-origatts="ident">English</tei-language>
            <tei-language ident="esp" data-origname="language" data-origatts="ident">Spanish</tei-language>
         </tei-langUsage>
      </tei-profileDesc>
 </tei-teiHeader>
 <tei-text data-origname="text">
   <tei-body data-origname="body">
   <tei-pb data-origname="pb" data-empty=""/>
   <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-name data-origname="name">Monsieur Acarete du Biscay's</tei-name> Journey from <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Ayres</tei-name> to <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Peru</tei-name>
</tei-head>
     <tei-div data-origname="div">
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            I Left <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Ayres</tei-name>, and took the Road I to <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Cordoua</tei-name>, leaving <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Santa Fe</tei-name> on my right hand, of which place take this account, <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'tis</tei-abbr> a Spanish Settlement dependant upon <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Ayres</tei-name>, the Commander is no more than a Lieutenant, and does nothing but by order from the Governor of <tei-name data-origname="name">Buenos Ayres</tei-name>. <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'Tis</tei-abbr> a little place containing <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">25</tei-num> Houses, without any Walls, Fortifications, or Garrison, distant <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">80</tei-num> Leagues from <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Ayres</tei-name> Northward, <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Situate</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Situated</tei-corr></tei-choice> upon the <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">River de la Plata</tei-name>, large Vessels might come up to it, were it not for a great bank that obstructs the passage a little above <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Ayres</tei-name>. 
            Nevertheless <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'tis</tei-abbr> a very advantageous Post, because <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'tis</tei-abbr> the only passage from <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Peru</tei-name>, <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Chili</tei-name> and <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Tucuman</tei-name> to <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Paraguay</tei-name>, and in a manner the Magazine of the Commodi<tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">ties</tei-fw> <tei-pb n="25" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> ties drawn from thence, particularly that Herb already spoken of, which they cannot be without in those Provinces. 
            The Soil is as good and Fertile here as at <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Ayres</tei-name>; and the Town having nothing remarkably different from what has been <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">observ'd</tei-abbr> of <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Ayres</tei-name>, I leave it, and proceed upon my Journey. <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'Tis</tei-abbr> counted <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">140</tei-num> Leagues from <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Ayres</tei-name> to <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Cordoua</tei-name>, and because some parts of the Road are uninhabited for a long way together; I furnished my self at my departure with what I was <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">inform'd</tei-abbr> I should stand in need of; so I set out having a Savage for my Guide, with <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">Three</tei-num> Horses and <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">Three</tei-num> Mules, some to carry my Baggage, and the rest to change upon the way when that I rid upon was tired.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            From <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Ayres</tei-name>, to the River <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Lucan</tei-name>, and even as far as the River <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Recife</tei-name>, <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">30</tei-num> Leagues, I <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">pass’d</tei-abbr> by several Habitations and Farms cultivated by the Spaniards, but beyond <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Recife</tei-name> to the <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">River Salladillo</tei-name>, I saw none. 
            Let it be observed by the way, that these Rivers as well as all the rest in the Provinces of <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Ayres</tei-name>, <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Paraguay</tei-name> and <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Tucuman</tei-name>, that fall into the <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">River de la Plata</tei-name> are fordable on Horse-back; but when the Rains or <tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">any</tei-fw> <tei-pb n="26" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> other accident swells them, a Traveller must either swim over, or else get upon a bundle in the nature of a raft, which a Savage hawls over to the other side. I could not Swim, and so was <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">forc'd</tei-abbr> to make use of this expedient twice or thrice when I could not find a Ford. The way was this, my Indian <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">kill'd</tei-abbr> a Wild Bull, <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">flead</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">flayed</tei-corr></tei-choice> the Hide off, stuffed it with straw, and <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">ty'd</tei-abbr> it up in a great bundle with thongs of the same Hide, upon which I <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">plac'd</tei-abbr> my self with my Baggage ; he swam over <tei-sic data-origname="sic">hawling</tei-sic> me after him by a Cord <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">ty'd</tei-abbr> to the bundle, and then he <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">repass'd</tei-abbr> and swam my Horses and Mules over to me.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            All the Country between the River <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Recife</tei-name> and <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Salladillo</tei-name>, <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">tho'</tei-abbr> uninhabited, abounds in Cattle and all sorts of Fruit trees, except Walnut and Chesnut-trees; there are whole Woods of Nectarine-Trees, <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">Three</tei-num> or <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">Four</tei-num> Leagues in compass, that bear excellent Fruit, which they not only eat raw, but bake them, or dry them in the Sun, to keep, as we in <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">France</tei-name> do Prunes: They seldom use any other than the Wood of this Tree for common firing at <tei-name data-origname="name">Buenos Ayres</tei-name>, and thereabouts. The Savages that dwell in these Parts are <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">distinguish'd</tei-abbr> into <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">two</tei-num> sorts, those that <tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">volunt-</tei-fw> <tei-pb n="27" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> voluntarily submit to the Spaniards are <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">call’d</tei-abbr> <tei-name data-origname="name">Panpistas</tei-name>, the rest <tei-name data-origname="name">Serranos</tei-name>, both <tei-sic data-origname="sic">cloathed</tei-sic> with Skins, but the last set up on the <tei-name data-origname="name">Panpistas</tei-name> as their mortal Enemies wherever they meet with them. All Fight on Horse-back, either with Lances pointed with Iron or Bones sharpen'd, or else with Bows and Arrows, they wear Bulls-hides <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">fashion'd</tei-abbr> like a Doublet without sleeves, to defend their Bodies. Their Chiefs that command over them in War and Peace, are <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">call’d</tei-abbr> <tei-name data-origname="name">Couracas</tei-name>. When they take any one of their Enemies, alive or dead, they meet all together, and after they have <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">reproach'd</tei-abbr> him, that either he or his Relations were the death of their Kindred or Friends, they cut and tear him into pieces, which they roast a little and eat, making a drinking Bowl of his <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Scull</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Skull</tei-corr></tei-choice>. They feed mostly upon flesh either raw or <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">dress'd</tei-abbr>, and particularly <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Colts</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Colt's</tei-corr></tei-choice> flesh, which they like better than Veal. They catch abundance of Fish likewise in their Rivers. They have no settled places of <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">aboad</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">abode</tei-corr></tei-choice>, but ramble up and down, several Families together, and live in Tents.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            I could not inform my self exactly what Religion they were of, but I was told that they <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">look'd</tei-abbr> upon the Sun and <tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">Moon</tei-fw> <tei-pb n="28" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> Moon as Deities and as I <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">travell'd</tei-abbr> along, I saw a Savage upon his knees with his Face to the Sun, who <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">cry'd</tei-abbr> out and made strange gestures with his Hands and Arms. I <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">learn'd</tei-abbr> from the Savage that <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">accompany'd</tei-abbr> me, that he was one of those they <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">call'd</tei-abbr> <tei-name data-origname="name">Papas</tei-name>, who in the Morning kneel towards the Sun, and at Night towards the Moon, to supplicate those <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">fancy'd</tei-abbr> Divinities to be propitious to them, to give them fair Weather, and Victory over their Foes.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            They make no great Ceremony in their Marriages ; but when a Relation dies, after they have <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">rubb’d</tei-abbr> his body with a certain Earth that consumes all but the Bones, they preserve them, and carry as many of them as they can conveniently about with them in a sort of Chests, and this they do in token of their affection to their Kindred ; indeed they are not wanting in good Offices to them during their Lives, nor in their Sickness and Death.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            Along the River <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Salladillo</tei-name>, I took notice of a great many Parrats, or <tei-name data-origname="name">Papagays</tei-name>, as the Spaniards call them, and certain Birds, <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">call’d</tei-abbr> <tei-name data-origname="name">Guacamayos</tei-name>, which are of divers Colours, and twice or thrice as big as a Parrat. The River it self is <tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">full</tei-fw> <tei-pb n="29" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> of the Fish, <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">call'd</tei-abbr> <tei-name data-origname="name">Dorado</tei-name>, which is very good to eat. There is also a Creature in it, whether <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'tis</tei-abbr> Meat or <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Poyson</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Poison</tei-corr></tei-choice> no body knows, it has Four Feet and a long Tail like a Lizard.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            From <tei-name data-origname="name">Salladillo</tei-name> quite to <tei-name data-origname="name">Cordoua</tei-name>, you go along a very fine River, that abounds with Fish, which is neither wide nor deep, for it may be forded over. On the Bank of it you meet with little Plantations every Three or Four Leagues ; which are like Country Houses inhabited by Spaniards, Portuguese, and the Natives, who have all the necessary accomodations of Life they can wish, and are very Civil and Charitable to Strangers; their principal Wealth is in Horses and Mules, in which they Trade with the Inhabitants of <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Peru</tei-name>.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Cordoua</tei-name> is a Town <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Situate</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Situated</tei-corr></tei-choice> in a pleasant and fruitful Plain upon the side of a River, bigger and broader than that I have just spoken of: <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'Tis</tei-abbr> <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">compos’d</tei-abbr> of about <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">400</tei-num> Houses, Built like those of <tei-name data-origname="name">Buenos Ayres</tei-name>. It has neither Ditches, nor Walls, nor Fort for its defence; He that Commands it is Governor of all the Provinces of <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Tucuman</tei-name>, and <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">tho’</tei-abbr> it be the place of his ordinary Residence, yet he is wont now and then, as he sees oc<tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">casion,</tei-fw> <tei-pb n="30" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> casion to go and pass some time at <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">St. Jago de l’Estro</tei-name>, at <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">St. Miguel de Tucuman</tei-name>, (which is the Capital City of the Province) at <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Salta</tei-name> and at <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Xuxui</tei-name>. In each of these Villages there is a Lieutenant, who has under him an Alcalde and some Officers for the Administration of Justice. The Bishop of <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Tucuman</tei-name> likewise usually resides at <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Cordoua</tei-name>, where the Cathedral is the only Parish Church of the whole Town, but there are divers Convents of Monks, namely of Dominicans, Recollects, and those of the <tei-name type="org" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Order de la Mercy</tei-name>: and one of Nunns. The Jesuits have a College there, and their <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Chappel</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Chapel</tei-corr></tei-choice> is the finest and richest of all.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            The Inhabitants are Rich in Gold and Silver, which they get by the Trade they have for Mules, with which they furnish <tei-name data-origname="name">Peru</tei-name> and other Parts; which is so considerable, that they sell about <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">28</tei-num> or <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">30000</tei-num> of <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr> every Year, which they breed up in their Farms. They usually keep <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr> till they are about <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">Two</tei-num> Years old, then expose <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr> to Sale, and have about <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">Six</tei-num> Patagons a piece for <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr>. The Merchants that come to buy <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr>, carry <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr> to <tei-name data-origname="name">St. Jago</tei-name>, to <tei-name data-origname="name">Salta</tei-name> and <tei-name data-origname="name">Xuxui</tei-name>, where they leave <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr> for <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">Three</tei-num> Years, till they are well grown and become <tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">strong,</tei-fw> <tei-pb n="31" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> and afterwards bring <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr> to <tei-name data-origname="name">Peru</tei-name>, where they presently have Vent for <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr>, because there as well as in the rest of the Western part of <tei-name data-origname="name">America</tei-name>, the greatest part of their Carriage is upon Mules. The People of <tei-name data-origname="name">Cordoua</tei-name> also drive a Trade in Cows, which they have from the <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Countrey</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Country</tei-corr></tei-choice> of <tei-name data-origname="name">Buenos Ayres</tei-name>, and carry to <tei-name data-origname="name">Peru</tei-name>, where without this way of Subsistance <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'tis</tei-abbr> certain they would have much ado to live. This kind of Traffick makes this Town the most considerable in the Province of <tei-name data-origname="name">Tucuman</tei-name>, as well for its Riches and Commodities, as for the Number of its Inhabitants, which are counted to be at least <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">5</tei-num> or <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">600</tei-num> Families, besides Slaves who are three times the number. But the generality of <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr> of all degrees have no other Arms but a Sword and Poignard, and are very indifferent <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Souldiers</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Soldiers</tei-corr></tei-choice>, the Air of the Country, and the Plenty they enjoy, rendring them Lazy and Cowardly.
            </tei-p>
          </tei-div>
     </tei-body>
 </tei-text>
</tei-TEI>

<tei-TEI data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" data-origname="TEI" data-origatts="xmlns:xi xmlns">
 <tei-teiHeader data-origname="teiHeader">
     <tei-fileDesc data-origname="fileDesc">
        <tei-titleStmt data-origname="titleStmt">
           <tei-title data-origname="title">A title</tei-title>
        </tei-titleStmt>
        <tei-publicationStmt data-origname="publicationStmt">
           <tei-p data-origname="p" data-empty=""/>
        </tei-publicationStmt>
        <tei-sourceDesc data-origname="sourceDesc">
           <tei-p data-origname="p" data-empty=""/>
        </tei-sourceDesc>
     </tei-fileDesc>
 </tei-teiHeader>
 <tei-text data-origname="text">
   <tei-body data-origname="body">
   <tei-pb data-origname="pb" data-empty=""/>
   <tei-head data-origname="head">Example</tei-head>
     <tei-div data-origname="div">
          <tei-p data-origname="p">
               An example
          </tei-p>
     </tei-div>
     </tei-body>
 </tei-text>
</tei-TEI>

<tei-TEI data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" data-origname="TEI" data-origatts="xmlns:xi xmlns">
 <tei-teiHeader data-origname="teiHeader">
     <tei-fileDesc data-origname="fileDesc">
        <tei-titleStmt data-origname="titleStmt">
           <tei-title data-origname="title">Viaje de Monsíenr Acárete du Biscay desde Buenos Aires hasta el Perú</tei-title>
           <tei-author data-origname="author">Du Biscay, Acarete</tei-author>
        </tei-titleStmt>
      <tei-publicationStmt data-origname="publicationStmt">
           <tei-p data-origname="p">Relación de un viaje al Río de la Plata y de allí por tierra al Perú con observaciones sobre los habitantes, sean indios o españoles, las ciudades, el comercio, la fertilidad y las riquezas de esta parte de América</tei-p>
        </tei-publicationStmt>
        <tei-sourceDesc data-origname="sourceDesc">
            <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">
  <tei-title data-origname="title">Viaje de Monsíenr Acárete du Biscay desde Buenos Aires hasta el Perú</tei-title>. En
 <tei-author data-origname="author">Acarete Du Biscay</tei-author>. <tei-publisher data-origname="publisher">La Gazeta de Buenos Aires</tei-publisher>. <tei-date data-origname="date">1867</tei-date>. </tei-bibl>
        </tei-sourceDesc>
     </tei-fileDesc>
     <tei-profileDesc data-origname="profileDesc">
         <tei-langUsage data-origname="langUsage">
            <tei-language ident="eng" data-origname="language" data-origatts="ident">English</tei-language>
            <tei-language ident="esp" data-origname="language" data-origatts="ident">Spanish</tei-language>
         </tei-langUsage>
      </tei-profileDesc>

 </tei-teiHeader>
 <tei-text data-origname="text">
   <tei-body data-origname="body">
   <tei-pb data-origname="pb" data-empty=""/>
   <tei-head data-origname="head">Viaje de <tei-name data-origname="name">Monsíenr Acárete du Biscay</tei-name> desde <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Aires</tei-name> hasta el <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Perú</tei-name></tei-head>
     <tei-div data-origname="div">
          <tei-p data-origname="p">
Salí de <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Aires</tei-name> y tomé el camino de <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Córdoba</tei-name>, dejando <tei-reg data-origname="reg">a</tei-reg> <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Santa Fe</tei-name> <tei-reg data-origname="reg">a</tei-reg> <tei-reg data-origname="reg">mi</tei-reg> derecha, de cuyo lugar, <tei-reg data-origname="reg">he</tei-reg> aquí una relación.</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">Desde <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Aires</tei-name> hasta el <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"> <tei-corr data-origname="corr">Río</tei-corr> deLucan</tei-name> <tei-ref target="#nota1" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">(1)</tei-ref> y aun hasta el <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Río</tei-corr> Recife</tei-name> <tei-ref target="#nota2" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">(2)</tei-ref> <tei-reg data-origname="reg">a</tei-reg> <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">30</tei-num> leguas del pueblo, pasé varias habitaciones y chacras cultivadas por los españoles, pero <tei-corr data-origname="corr">más</tei-corr> allá del <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Recife</tei-name> <tei-corr data-origname="corr">hasta</tei-corr> el <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"> <tei-corr data-origname="corr">Río </tei-corr> Saladillo</tei-name>, no vi ninguna. Observaré de paso, que tanto estos <tei-corr data-origname="corr">ríos</tei-corr> como los demás de las provincias de <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Aires</tei-name>, <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Paraguay</tei-name> y <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Tucumán</tei-corr></tei-name>, que desaguan en el <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Río</tei-corr> de la Plata</tei-name>, son vadeables <tei-corr data-origname="corr">a </tei-corr> caballo, pero cuando las lluvias <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> o </tei-corr> cualesquier accidente los hace crecer, el viajero se <tei-corr data-origname="corr">ve</tei-corr> obligado <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> atravesarlos nadando, sino <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> o </tei-corr> colocarse sobre un bulto en forma de balsa que un salvaje pasa tirando al lado opuesto. No <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> sabía </tei-corr> yo nadar, y por lo mismo tuve dos <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> o </tei-corr> tres veces que acudir <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> este <tei-corr data-origname="corr">expediente</tei-corr> cuando no encontraba paso. El modo de verificarlo era este: mi indio mataba un toro, desollábalo, y rellenando el cuero de paja, cerraba y aseguraba <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> este con correas del mismo cuero; colocábame yo sobre él, y el indio cruzaba el <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> río </tei-corr> nadando, llevándome tras de sí por medio de una soga atada al bulto; repasando el <tei-corr data-origname="corr">río</tei-corr> en seguida, <tei-corr data-origname="corr">hacía </tei-corr> pasar <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> nado los caballos y <tei-sic data-origname="sic">muías</tei-sic> adonde yo estaba.</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">Todo el país entre el <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"> <tei-corr data-origname="corr">Río </tei-corr> Recife</tei-name> y <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Saladillo</tei-name>, aun cuando no está poblado, abunda en ganados y árboles frutales de todas clases, menos el nogal y el castaño. Hay montes enteros de durazneros, de tres <tei-corr data-origname="corr">a </tei-corr> <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">cuatro</tei-num> leguas de ostensión que producen excelente fruta, que no solo comen <tei-sic data-origname="sic">ert</tei-sic> su estado natural sino que también la cuecen, <tei-corr data-origname="corr">o </tei-corr> secan al sol, para conservarla, así como hacemos nosotros en Francia con las ciruelas. En <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Aires</tei-name> y sus inmediaciones, raras veces se echa mano de otro combustible para los usos comunes, que el de la madera de este árbol.</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">Los salvajes que moran en estos lugares, se dividen en dos clases; aquellos que se someten voluntariamente <tei-corr data-origname="corr">a</tei-corr> los españoles, llámaseles Pampistas, y los demás Serranos. Unos y otros visten pieles, pero estos últimos, do quiera los encuentren, atacan <tei-corr data-origname="corr">a</tei-corr> los <tei-corr data-origname="corr">Pampistas</tei-corr> como <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> sus enemigos mortales. Todos ellos pelean <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> caballo, ya con lanzas enhastadas con <tei-corr data-origname="corr">fierro</tei-corr> <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> o </tei-corr> hueso aguzado, <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> o </tei-corr> bien con arcos y flechas. Usan una especie de justillo de cuero de toro, para defender el cuerpo. Los jefes que los comandan, tanto en la guerra como en la paz, llámanles <tei-name data-origname="name">Curacas</tei-name>. Cuando toman alguno de sus enemigos, ya sea vivo <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> o </tei-corr> muerto, <tei-sic data-origname="sic">^e</tei-sic> reúnen todos, y después de reprocharle que él <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> o </tei-corr> sus parientes ocasionaron la muerte de sus deudos <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> o </tei-corr> amigos, lo despedazan, y soazándolo un poco se lo comen, <tei-corr data-origname="corr">convirtiendo</tei-corr> el cráneo en <tei-corr data-origname="corr">vasijas</tei-corr> para beber. Se alimentan principalmente de carne cruda <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> o </tei-corr> cocida, y particularmente de carne de potrillo, que prefieren <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> la de ternera. Toman en los nos pescado en abundancia y no tienen morada <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> fija</tei-corr>, sino que vagan de un lado <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> otro con sus familias, viviendo en toldos.</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">No pude averiguar con exactitud de qué religión eran, pero dijéronme que <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> tenían </tei-corr> al sol y la luna por deidades, y <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> mi paso vi un salvaje arrodillado con la cara hacia el sol, que daba gritos y accionaba de un modo <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> extraño </tei-corr> con los brazos y las manos. Supe por el salvaje que me acompañaba, que era uno de aquellos <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> quienes llaman <tei-name data-origname="name">Papas</tei-name>, quienes por la mañana se arrodillan mirando al sol y en la noche <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> la luna, para suplicará <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> aquellas supuestas divinidades que les sean propicias, que les <tei-sic data-origname="sic">conceda</tei-sic> buen tiempo y la victoria sobre sus enemigos.</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">No son de gran aparato las ceremonias en sus casamientos; pero cuando muere un pariente, después de haber dado friegas al cuerpo con cierta tierra que todo lo consume menos los huesos, conservan estos, llevando consigo cuantos pueden en una especie de cajones, y esto lo hacen en prueba de afecto <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> sus deudos; y en verdad no faltan en sus buenos oficios <tei-corr data-origname="corr">hacia</tei-corr> ellos durante sus vidas, ni aun en sus enfermedades y en su muerte.</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">Por la costa del <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Saladillo</tei-name> observé gran número de loros, <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> o </tei-corr> según les llaman los españoles, papagallos, y ciertos pájaros llamados guacamayos, que son de diversos colores y dos <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> o </tei-corr> tres veces <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> más </tei-corr> grandes que un loro. El <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> río </tei-corr> está lleno del pescado que llaman dorado. También hállase en él un animal de cuatro patas y con cola como un lagarto, pero si es bueno como alimento, <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> o </tei-corr> nocivo, nadie lo sabe.</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">Del <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Saladillo</tei-name> hasta <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Córdoba</tei-name>, se sigue costeando un hermoso <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> río </tei-corr>, que abunda en pescado, y que no es ni ancho ni profundo, pudiéndose vadearlo. Sobre las barrancas de él encuéntranse haciendas <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> cada tres <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> o </tei-corr> <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">cuatro</tei-num> leguas, que son como casas de campo, habitadas por españoles, portugueses <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> e </tei-corr> hijos del país en donde tienen todas las comodidades de la vida que pueden apetecer, y son muy corteses y caritativos para con los <tei-corr data-origname="corr">extraños</tei-corr>. Su principal riqueza consiste en caballos y <tei-sic data-origname="sic">muías</tei-sic>, con los que trafican con los habitantes de <tei-name data-origname="name">Perú</tei-name>.</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Córdoba</tei-name> es un pueblo situado en una llanura agradable y feraz, <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> la margen de un <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> río </tei-corr> <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> más </tei-corr>  grande y <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> más </tei-corr> ancho que el de que acabo de hablar. Se compone como de <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">400</tei-num> casas construidas como las de <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Aires</tei-name>. No tienen fosos, murallas ni fortaleza para su defensa. El que manda <tei-corr data-origname="corr">allí</tei-corr> es <tei-name type="personRoleName" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Gobernador</tei-name> de todas las provincias de <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"> <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> Tucumán</tei-corr></tei-name>, y aun cuando este es el lugar de su residencia ordinaria, sin embargo, acostumbra de vez en cuando, según lo cree conveniente, ir <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> pasar algún tiempo en <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Santiago del Estero</tei-name>, en <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">San Miguel de <tei-corr data-origname="corr">Tucumán</tei-corr> </tei-name> (que es la ciudad capital de la Provincia) en <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Salta</tei-name> <tei-corr data-origname="corr">o </tei-corr> en <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"> <tei-sic data-origname="sic">Xuxui</tei-sic></tei-name>. En cada uno de estos pueblitos existe un <tei-name type="personRoleName" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">teniente</tei-name>, que tiene bajo sus órdenes un <tei-name type="personRoleName" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"> Alcalde</tei-name> y algunos <tei-name type="personRoleName" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">oficiales</tei-name> para la administración de justicia. El <tei-name type="personRoleName" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"> obispo </tei-name> de <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Tucumán</tei-corr></tei-name> también reside ordinariamente en <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Córdoba</tei-name>, en donde la Catedral es la única iglesia parroquial que hay en todo el pueblo; pero hay varios conventos de <tei-name type="personRoleName" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">frailes</tei-name>, <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> saber, de <tei-name type="org" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Dominicos</tei-name>, <tei-name type="org" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Recoletos</tei-name>, y de la <tei-name type="org" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Orden de la Merced</tei-name>; y uno de <tei-name type="personRoleName" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">monjas</tei-name>. Los <tei-name type="org" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Jesuítas</tei-name> tienen <tei-corr data-origname="corr">allí</tei-corr> un colegio, y su Capilla es la <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> más </tei-corr> rica y <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> más </tei-corr> hermosa de todas.</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">Los habitantes son ricos en oro y plata, adquiridos por el comercio que hacen de <tei-sic data-origname="sic">muías</tei-sic>, supliendo de ellas al <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Perú</tei-name> y otros puntos; y es tan considerable <tei-corr data-origname="corr">este</tei-corr> que venden de <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">28</tei-num> <tei-corr data-origname="corr">a </tei-corr> <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type"> 30,000 </tei-num> al año, que <tei-corr data-origname="corr">crían </tei-corr> en sus haciendas. Generalmente las conservan hasta que tienen <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">dos </tei-num> años poniéndolas entonces <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> venta, obteniendo por ellas <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> razón como de <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">seis </tei-num> patacones por cada una. Los mercaderes que vienen <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a</tei-corr></tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">comprarlas las llevan <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"> Santiago</tei-name>, <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Salta</tei-name> y <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"> <tei-sic data-origname="sic">Xuxui</tei-sic><tei-ref target="#nota3" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">(3)</tei-ref> </tei-name>, donde las conservan tres años hasta que se hayan creado y robustecido bien, llevándolas después al <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Perú</tei-name>, en donde las venden sin demora, porque <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> allí</tei-corr>, como en el resto de la <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">América occidental</tei-name>, la mayor parte de las conducciones se hacen <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr> lomo de <tei-sic data-origname="sic">muía</tei-sic>.</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">Las gentes de <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Córdoba</tei-name> trafican también en vacas que conducen desde los campos de <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Aires</tei-name> hasta el <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Perú</tei-name> en donde, sin este medio de subsistencia, ciertamente les <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> sería</tei-corr> muy difícil vivir. Este negocio hace que este pueblo sea el <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> más</tei-corr> considerable <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> de los</tei-corr> de la <tei-name type="placeGeog" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Provincia de <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> Tucumán</tei-corr></tei-name>, tanto por sus riquezas y artículos de comercio, cuanto por el número de sus habitantes, que se calculan entre  <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type"> quinientas </tei-num>  <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> a </tei-corr>  <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type"> seiscientas </tei-num>  familias, <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> además</tei-corr> de los esclavos, que montan <tei-sic data-origname="sic">átres</tei-sic> tantos <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> más</tei-corr>.</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">Pero las clases todas, en general, no tienen <tei-corr data-origname="corr"> más</tei-corr> arma que espada y puñal, y como <tei-name type="personRoleName" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">soldados</tei-name> son de muy escaso mérito, pues el aire del país y la abundancia de que gozan, los hace <tei-sic data-origname="sic">holgazines</tei-sic> y cobardes.</tei-p>


<tei-note xml:id="nota1" id="nota1" data-origname="note" data-origatts="xml:id">1. Lujan.</tei-note>
<tei-note xml:id="nota2" id="nota2" data-origname="note" data-origatts="xml:id">2. Arrecifes.</tei-note>
<tei-note xml:id="nota3" id="nota3" data-origname="note" data-origatts="xml:id">3. Jujuy.</tei-note>



     </tei-div>
     </tei-body>
 </tei-text>
</tei-TEI>
